text:
144-150 East 49th Street, south side, between Lexington and Third Avenues.
About 1924.

Underwood & Underwood.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

Lexington Avenue, east side, north from 49th Street, showing at N. E. corner old Biblical Seminary Building.
October 29, 1927.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

49th Street, north side, from Lexington to Park Avenues. The Adams Express Company on Lexington Avenue has already been demolished, and the power plant in the centre of this picture will soon go to make way for the new Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
July 30, 1929.

P. L. Sperr..

49th Street, north side, west from but not including Lexington Avenue, showing in the foreground the clearing for the new Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

March 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Lexington Avenue, west side, south from E. 49th Street, as viewed from the Hotel Beverly at the N. E. corner of 50th Street. Constructional details seen are for the new Waldorf-Astoria. Across same appears the 14 story Barclay. This is at the S. W. corner. Above this is the towering Grand Central Building. To the left of the latter are the dim outlines of the Lincoln and the Chanin Buildings.

May 3, 1930
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

Lexington Avenue, west side, south from E. 49th Street, as viewed from the Hotel Beverly at the N. E. corner of 50th Street. Constructional details seen are for the new Waldorf-Astoria. Across same appears the 14 story Barclay. This is at the S. W. corner. Above this is the towering Grand Central Building. To the left of the latter are the dim outlines of the Lincoln and the Chanin Buildings.

May 3, 1930
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

Lexington Avenue, west side, south from E. 49th Street, as viewed from the Hotel Beverly at the N.E. corner of 50th Street. Constructional details seen are for the new Waldorf-Astoria. Across same appears the 14 story Barclay. This is at the S.W. corner. Above this is the towering Grand Central Building. To the left of the latter are the dim outlines of the Lincoln and Chanin Buildings.

May 3, 1930
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

Lexington Avenue, west side, south from E. 49th Street, as viewed from the Hotel Beverly at the N.E. corner of 50th Street. Constructional details seen are for the new Waldorf-Astoria. Across same appears the 14 story Barclay. This is at the S.W. corner. Above this is the towering Grand Central Building. To the left of the latter are the dim outlines of the Lincoln and Chanin Buildings.

May 3, 1930
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

Lexington Avenue (center, view), at East 49th Street (intersection seen across clearance) showing the new Hotel Waldorf Astoria site, as viewed south eastward from the Columbia Broadcasting Company Building at No. 485 Madison Avenue (S.E. corner of 52nd Street). This will occupy the entire block from Park to Lexington Avenues, between 50th and 49th Streets and to the south of St. Bartholomews P.E. Church. Surrounding same are numerous hotels which from left to right are, the 30 storied Beverly; the 15 storied Montclair; the 31 storied Shelton; the 14 storied Barclay; and (across the roof of the latter) the 25 storied Lexington. Beyond these, in the same order, are the various printing and publishing buildings; Tudor City and the Daily News Building. The East River and its Brooklyn shore form a background for these Grand Central zone edifices. Note the absence of the present General Electric (originally the R.C.A.) Building which would appear over the Church roof and obstruct a view of the Hotel Beverly.

March 4, 1930.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

Lexington Avenue (center, view), at East 49th Street (intersection seen across clearance) showing the new Hotel Waldorf Astoria site, as viewed south eastward from the Columbia Broadcasting Company Building at No. 485 Madison Avenue (S.E. corner of 52nd Street). This will occupy the entire block from Park to Lexington Avenues, between 50th and 49th Streets and to the south of St. Bartholomews P.E. Church. Surrounding same are numerous hotels which from left to right are, the 30 storied Beverly; the 15 storied Montclair; the 31 storied Shelton; the 14 storied Barclay; and (across the roof of the latter) the 25 storied Lexington. Beyond these, in the same order, are the various printing and publishing buildings; Tudor City and the Daily News Building. The East River and its Brooklyn shore form a background for these Grand Central zone edifices. Note the absence of the present General Electric (originally the R.C.A.) Building which would appear over the Church roof and obstruct a view of the Hotel Beverly.

March 4, 1930.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

Lexington Avenue, west side, from 49th to 50th Streets, showing the upper end of the Grand Central railroad yards in the block where the new Hotel Waldorf-Astoria is being erected. The cars in the right foreground are directly below the site of the Adams Express Building, which has just been demolished. The rest of the block was occupied by the railroad power plant and Y. M. C. A. March 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
